subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Here I am
once again without an agenda, but a few
little things I should point out. One is
that I am traveling. By the time
you watch this I'll be on the road. I've
got trips scheduled to Dallas and to
Chicago. I'm going to take my computer
with me, my big computer, but obviously
I'm not taking the whole studio, so it's
possible that while I'm traveling I'll
just make some videos using the camera
on my computer and upload them. I
like working here in the studio because
I know I've got good sound quality and
good lighting and I'm just accustomed to
the studio. I like the black
background, for example. But it's not
necessary to always use the studio.
After all, just a couple of days
ago when I recorded some karaoke,
I made the whole recording on my iPhone.
Also, with regard to interviews, I can
tell you for those of you who are
staying tuned, I have just uploaded the
last interview that I have in my backlog
of interviews and I don't have any
scheduled for a while, so it may be a
while before new interviews get posted.
We'll see. Things can happen on short
notice. I guess this is a good time
to reflect on this process, these daily
monologues, in a sense. What is
it about? What do I get out of it
and what do you get out of it, from these
daily monologues? Speaking for myself,
I can say this: I love doing this and I
do have a sense that I'm getting better
at it. I used to hem and haw quite a bit
more than I do now. I think
I have more of a natural sensibility for
myself and I do get the sense that
the more I do it, the little creative
things are happening. For me,
I guess it's fair enough to say, it's
part of my own growth process and I'm
enjoying it. So, I'll keep doing it as
long as it continues to be enjoyable for
me. Why not? I see, you know, that
within 2-3 days there's typically
over a thousand people watching each of
these monologues, so I have to assume
that those of you who watch, and I know
some are regular watchers, some are
sporadic viewers,
you're probably engaging in a growth
process yourself.
That's sort of what I have in
mind and that is, you know, a little
10-minute tickler, every day, I think can
help stimulate something going on in
the depths of the psyche, some kind of
openings. I know it will be different
for everybody but that's really what I'm
endeavoring to do here, is a little
10-minute psychological, spiritual,
parapsychological stimulus each day. A
little 10-minute stimulus, I
think helps start the day, helps finish
the day. It's a good reminder.
For some of you, I think, [it's] a source of
inspiration. For other people, it's a way
to satisfy your curiosity about my
discipline of parapsychology, a
discipline that most people are very
curious about. Naturally, you don't
need this. There are lots of books
available if you wanted to upgrade your
knowledge of parapsychology, but it's
nice, I should think, if I were a viewer,
I would say it's nice
to be able to have a sense of the
presence of a person who has devoted
their life to this discipline. It's not
just reading a book where you get
information, it's more a sense of
presence. That's why I call this series
of monologues "In Presence," because I'm
here present with you for better or
worse. Now, I just read, John Paul posted a
very provocative comment and I just read
it and it's on my mind so I will see if
I can address it. He said, "This is
becoming, it's morphing into a vanity
project. The next thing you know you're
going to make us one of your video
monologues while you're sitting on the
toilet and all of your peanut gallery
supporters are going to be applauding
and laughing." What an image. I
suppose if I'm thinking about being
experimental, could I possibly try
something like that? I used to watch
some situation comedy shows on
television where they would show
characters sitting on the toilet while
one of them is talking to another, so
it's not exactly a new frontier any
longer, even on mainstream network
television. But yeah, I think I am
reaching in my own mind for a new
frontier, like how far can I push this?
Could I just snap my finger and
people would be psychic? Just like that.
You know, it's almost as if I could, I
would. For example, back in the 1970s when
Uri Geller was all the rage and I had
him on my radio show several times back
at KPFA FM in Berkeley, but the point
is that when Geller got on the radio or
TV, thousands of people
experienced unusual paranormal events
taking place in their own homes as they
were watching him. Who knows what
triggered that? They were called mini-
Gellers and young people would
discover they could bend spoons and then
there were spoon bending parties all
around the country. You know, it
was like a "happening." I don't think
that's quite what I'm going for here. I
think I'm trying to do something that
might be a little more far-reaching, a
little deeper, and maybe even a little more
permanent than a "happening." In a way, my
10 minutes or 15 minutes a day with you
is... Well, not long ago I talked about how
the UFOs may be influencing humanity at
a subtle level that we don't even know.
People say there's nothing there. There's
nothing there at all. But there they are
in the background, on the margins of our
culture, and probably having over time an
extraordinary influence that none of us
can actually see because we're too close
to it and it's happening perhaps too
slowly. That influence ultimately is
about opening up the depths of the mind
in different ways. For some people it
will be a question of acquiring certain
skills, siddhis, powers, psi experiences.
For other people it may be just
getting more in touch with themselves.
For other people it may be just
appreciating more what people around
them are going through. I don't knowâ€¦
I don't know exactly. And yes, there's an
element of vanity here. I don't know that
anybody who didn't have a certain level
of ego, a certain level
of vanity would be doing this at all. But now, for
those of you who are viewing, who are
listening, how can I make it even better
for you? I don't have all the answers
by any means but what I do find is I get
interesting comments to respond to. I
don't know if I've really addressed the
point that John Paul was trying to
make. I think what he was saying
is that maybe I'm going a little too far,
I'm pushing things maybe to such an
extreme that something is getting lost
or that my ego is taking over in ways
that I don't even see. That's a good
one. That's a good one to reflect on. I'm
going to look at that. And I guess what I
could do at the same time is to suggest
to each of you that may be an issue for
you to look at. Are there
times when your ego kind of sneaks out
and gets control of you in ways that you
don't notice? And that you may think that
you're behaving in a way that is very
giving and very selfless and actually
what it is, is like a total ego trip?
I think that may be what John Paul was
suggesting and if it's the case that
that was the suggestion, thank you for
that. It's worth taking a good look at.
Maybe while I'm traveling I'll have
opportunities to do that. So, I'm not
going to leave you with anything. I'll
leave you with this, make of this
what you will. As I mentioned things
are going to be sporadic now for a while.
And I hope that when I'm back here
you'll be here too. Thank you for being
with me.
